questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure, with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide

 

Furosemide can be used in this patient. All the other drugs mentioned are avoided due to the risk of hyperkalemia.

 

Beta – blockers- interferes with beta 2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake.

 

ACE Inhibitors- inhibition of angiotensin II formation with a decrease in aldosterone secretion.

 

Angiotensin II receptors blockers (ARBS)- block AT1 receptor, decreasing in aldosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Typically avoided if there's a risk of hyperkalemia, as it can be dangerous in elevated potassium levels, potentially causing cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Being a potassium-sparing diuretic, it is contraindicated in patients with high serum potassium levels as it could exacerbate hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Enalapril: As an ACE inhibitor, it can increase potassium levels by reducing aldosterone secretion, thus inappropriate for patients already presenting with hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In heart failure patients with elevated potassium levels, loop diuretics like furosemide are preferred to manage fluid overload and avoid exacerbation of hyperkalemia, unlike potassium-sparing diuretics or ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

Enterococci are gram-positive bacteria, and the first-line treatment for enterococcal infections is typically ampicillin. However, in patients with penicillin allergies, vancomycin is the preferred alternative. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including enterococci. It works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis, leading to bacterial cell death.

 

 

  • Linezolid               
  • Tigecycline (Complicated Skin/Intra-abdominal Infections)
  • Daptomycin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: This is a monobactam antibiotic that is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria particularly in community-acquired pneumonia in ICU patients with a penicillin allergy, Aztreonam is the best choice.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. While effective against some gram-positive bacteria, it is not the preferred choice for enterococcal infections, especially in patients with penicillin allergies due to the risk of cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: This is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic. It would not be safe to use in a patient with a penicillin allergy due to the risk of a severe allergic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with penicillin allergies who have enterococcal infections, vancomycin is the preferred and safe alternative for treatment.

choices.text: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient's hands is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Early diagnosis of RA is crucial. May present with mono/oligoarthritis. Inflammation (stiffness > 30 mins) is significant.

 

RA +ve: 70%, anti-CCP+ve:75%. Hence 1/5th SERONEGATIVE

 

Rule out Psoriatic arthritis, Crystal arthropathies, CTD, Hansens, Polymyalgia rheumatica before labeling seronegative RA

 

Get baseline CBC, LFT, RFT, HbsAg, Anti-HCV

 

Start DMARD - Mtx 7.5-10 mg/week, gradually ↑ to 25 mg/wk. Avoid DMARDs cocktail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. OA usually morning stiffness <15-30 mins. Bouchard, Heberden nodes in late stages.

 

Option C. Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is a condition that can develop after peripheral nerve injury, wherein patients experience unprovoked pain in the area supplied by the affected nerve. Sympathetic innervation to the affected area can be disrupted, and blocking this sympathetic activity with a local anesthetic can sometimes alleviate the pain. Notably, damaged nerve fibers become sensitive to adrenergic signals, allowing them to be activated by the sympathetic nervous system. This constellation of symptoms, including spontaneous pain and signs of disrupted sympathetic function, characterizes CRPS.

 

Option D. Villonodular Synovitis is characterized by joint swelling due to excess synovial growth and potential bleeding into the joint, leading to pain and restricted movement, which is less likely given the chronic symmetrical joint involvement typical of RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid Arthritis is suggested by the presence of symmetrical small joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the morning, with potential visible joint deformities. Early and aggressive treatment is vital to manage symptoms and prevent progressive joint damage.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap

questions.text: The antibodies typically elevated in primary biliary cirrhosis are? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-mitochondrial antibodies

 

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA) are the hallmark serological marker for primary biliary cirrhosis (now termed primary biliary cholangitis). These antibodies are highly specific, with >95% of patients having AMA directed against the PDC-E2 pattern. The presence of these antibodies, along with elevated IgM levels and compatible histology, represents the classic diagnostic triad for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-actin antibodies: These antibodies (smooth muscle antibodies) are characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis type I, not primary biliary cholangitis. Smooth muscle antibodies (SMA) are typically seen in autoimmune hepatitis along with antinuclear antibodies.

 

Option B. Antinuclear antibodies: While antinuclear antibodies may be present in some patients with primary biliary cholangitis, they are more characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis type I, particularly with a homogeneous pattern.

 

Option D. Anti-soluble liver antigen antibodies: These antibodies are associated with autoimmune hepatitis type III, not primary biliary cholangitis. Anti-SLA serves as a marker for this subtype of autoimmune hepatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary biliary cholangitis (formerly called primary biliary cirrhosis) has a highly specific serological marker - anti-mitochondrial antibodies - which are found in >95% of patients and target the PDC-E2 pattern, making them a valuable diagnostic tool for this condition.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular diastole


Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are classic early diastolic murmurs heard during ventricular diastole, when blood flows back into the left ventricle from the aorta.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ventricular ejection: Associated with systolic murmurs.
 

Option B. Throughout cardiac cycle: Associated with continuous murmurs, like in PDA.
 

Option C. Isovolumetric contraction: Not typically associated with murmurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation murmurs are heard during ventricular diastole

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

History suggestive of cramps, muscle weakness is common in hypokalemia. ECG shows PR, QTc prolongation, T wave inversion, u waves. “NikEleKam T waves aka reverse wellen sign” seen in Hypokalemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Typically, hyperkalemia would show peaked T waves, widened QRS complexes, and possibly a flattened P wave, which are not evident in this ECG.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Would more typically show a prolonged QT interval but lacks the specific U wave features seen in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: This condition would likely show a shortened QT interval, which is not present in this ECG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECG Findings in Hypokalemia:

 

  • U-waves
  • Prolonged QTc
  • Flattened/inverted Ts
  • Sagging ST
  • ST Depression
  • Biphasic t-waves
  • ST elevation in aVR
  • PVCs/Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • Pseudo-ischemic patterns

questions.text:
Chronic HBV infection would be consistent with which of the following serology? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. HBsAg
  2. Anti-HBsAg
  3. Anti-HBcAg
  4. HBV DNA
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): This antibody appears after the infection has been cleared or following successful vaccination. It indicates immunity to HBV. In chronic HBV infection, this antibody is not present since the surface antigen is still active.

 

Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is defined by the persistence of the surface antigen (HBsAg) for more than six months. The presence of HBsAg indicates an active HBV infection.

 

Serological markers:

 

1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen indicates that the person is infectious. It is found in the blood during acute and chronic HBV infection. The presence of HBsAg for more than six months defines chronic HBV infection.

 

3. Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): This antibody indicates previous or ongoing infection with HBV. In chronic infection, the IgG fraction of anti-HBc is usually present.

 

4. HBV DNA: The presence of HBV DNA in the blood indicates active viral replication. It is usually detectable in chronic HBV infection, although the levels can vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic HBV infection is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg, the presence of Anti-HBc, and usually detectable HBV DNA. Anti-HBs is not present in chronic HBV infection as it indicates immunity.

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypothermia

 

Osborn waves, also known as J-waves, are characteristic findings on an ECG that are typically associated with hypothermia. These waves appear as a positive deflection at the J point (the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment) and are most evident in moderate to severe cases of hypothermia. The appearance of Osborn waves is thought to be caused by a disparity in the action potential durations between the epicardial and endocardial surfaces of the heart during ventricular repolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: This condition does not typically cause Osborn waves. Instead, hypothyroidism can lead to other ECG changes such as bradycardia, low voltage, and possibly prolonged QT interval.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: This typically leads to a prolonged QT interval but does not cause Osborn waves.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: While hypokalemia can cause significant ECG changes, including U waves, flattened T waves, and ST depression, it is not associated with Osborn waves.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

J-wave or Osborn wave is seen in cases of moderate or severe hypothermia due to increase in the epicardial potassium current relative to that of endocardium during ventricular repolarization.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the right knee. Synovial fluid analysis shows rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pseudogout

 

Explanation:


Pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease, CPPD) is characterized by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints. Key features include:

  • Acute pain and swelling of the knee: The knee is the most commonly affected joint in pseudogout, unlike gout which frequently involves the first MTP joint.
  • Synovial fluid findings: Rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy confirm the diagnosis.
  • Normal serum uric acid levels: This differentiates pseudogout from gout.

Pseudogout is more common in elderly patients but can also occur in middle-aged individuals, especially in the context of metabolic disorders or alcohol use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute gout: Incorrect because gout is characterized by monosodium urate crystals, which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent, and it commonly affects the first MTP joint rather than the knee.

 

Option C. Reactive arthritis: Incorrect because this condition typically follows gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections and is associated with asymmetrical polyarthritis, often involving the lower extremities, along with other features like conjunctivitis or urethritis.

 

Option D. Septic arthritis: Incorrect because septic arthritis usually presents with systemic symptoms like fever, marked leukocytosis, and more severe joint destruction. The presence of crystals in the synovial fluid strongly suggests a crystal-induced arthropathy, not septic arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:


Pseudogout is characterized by acute joint pain and swelling, most commonly affecting the knee, with synovial fluid findings of rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. Differentiation from gout and septic arthritis is critical for appropriate management.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to Vitamin D toxicity? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dexamethasone

 

Dexamethasone is utilized in the treatment of hypercalcemia, particularly when induced by Vitamin D toxicity. This corticosteroid helps reduce calcium absorption from the intestine and increase calcium excretion, effectively lowering serum calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: Used primarily as an antimalarial and in autoimmune diseases, it does not play a role in managing hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Hydroxychloroquine: Similar to chloroquine, used for autoimmune disorders but not for hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Ketoconazole: An antifungal medication that can reduce corticosteroid production but is not specifically used to treat hypercalcemia caused by Vitamin D toxicity

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone, Bisphosphonates, IV fluids, Loop diuretics, Calcitonin are used in the management of Hypercalcemia.

 

Reference - (Harrison/Endocrinology/Hypercalcemia)

choices.text: Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

questions.text: A patient with CKD with refractory hypertension is brought to the casualty with dizziness. His BP was found to be 200/120 mmHg. His BUN was 50 mg/dl and creatinine was 3 mg/dl. Potassium was 6 mEq/L. Which of the following is an indication of emergency hemodialysis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated in several critical conditions commonly remembered with the mnemonic AEIOU:

 

  1. Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis that is not responsive to standard medical therapy, particularly when the pH is less than 7.1.
  2. Electrolyte imbalance: Severe hyperkalemia, especially when potassium levels are more than 6.5 mEq/L, rapidly rising, or refractory to medical management.
  3. Intoxications: With dialyzable drugs.
  4. Overload: Volume overload state, such as diuretic-resistant pulmonary edema, particularly when oxygen requirements are increasing.
  5. Uremia: Uremic complications such as pericarditis or encephalopathy, which are urgent indications due to the risk of tamponade or severe cognitive impairment.

 

In this patient, severe acidosis, alongside elevated BUN and creatinine, is a strong indication for emergency hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Hypertension alone, even when severe, is not an immediate indication for emergency hemodialysis

 

Option C. Potassium level of 6 mEq/L: While elevated, a potassium level of 6 mEq/L by itself is not enough to indicate emergency dialysis unless it is rapidly rising or refractory to treatment. Typically, levels above 6.5 mEq/L are considered more critical.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: This is not an indication for emergency hemodialysis. Instead, metabolic acidosis, especially when severe and refractory to treatment, is a more significant concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidosis, refractory hyperkalemia, volume overload, intoxications, and uremic complications. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine is a critical indication for initiating emergency hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady develops sudden onset facial deviation with slurring of speech and inability to raise right arm. The symptoms spontaneously begin to reduce and has significant improvement over the next 48 hours. She has a mid-diastolic murmur on auscultation and irregular heart rhythm. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardio-embolic stroke

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with sudden onset neurological deficits (facial deviation, slurred speech, and right arm weakness), which improved significantly over 48 hours. The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur suggests mitral stenosis, and the irregular heart rhythm indicates atrial fibrillation. These are strong risk factors for cardio-embolic stroke. Although the improvement suggests a transient ischemic attack (TIA), the symptoms lasted more than 24 hours, which aligns with the definition of a stroke rather than a TIA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TIA: By definition, a TIA's symptoms resolve within 24 hours. Since the symptoms persisted for more than 24 hours, this is not a TIA.

 

Option B. Thrombo-embolic stroke: While possible, the presence of mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation makes cardio-embolic stroke more likely.

 

Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus from the venous system passes through a right-to-left cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale) into the arterial system. There is no mention of such a shunt or a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardio-embolic stroke should be suspected in patients with sudden onset neurological deficits and risk factors such as mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation. Symptoms persisting for more than 24 hours distinguish stroke from TIA.

choices.text: Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space
CT scan of the chest

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema, respiratory distress, and hypotension. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side and a hyper-resonant note was felt on percussion. X-ray is shown. What will be your immediate management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space

 

The clinical presentation of subcutaneous emphysema, respiratory distress, hypotension, absent air entry, and hyper-resonant note on percussion strongly suggests a tension pneumothorax. This condition is confirmed by the X-ray, which shows a dark lung field on the right side due to air in the pleural space, a collapsed lung border, and a shift of the mediastinum and trachea to the left side.

 

Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to relieve the pressure in the pleural space. The recommended immediate management is needle thoracostomy, which involves the insertion of a wide-bore needle into the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line to rapidly decompress the pleural space, followed by the insertion of a chest drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent tracheostomy: This is not the immediate management for tension pneumothorax. Tracheostomy is typically performed to secure the airway in cases of upper airway obstruction.

 

Option C. IV fluids: While IV fluids may be administered to manage hypotension, they do not address the underlying cause of tension pneumothorax and are not the immediate life-saving intervention required.

 

Option D. CT scan of the chest: Imaging studies like a CT scan are not performed immediately in cases of tension pneumothorax due to the urgent need for decompression to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate management for tension pneumothorax is needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line, followed by the insertion of a chest drain.

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti HBs

 

After recovery from hepatitis B infection, the patient will have antibodies against the hepatitis B surface antigen (anti-HBS), indicating immunity. The key points related to hepatitis B infection and recovery include:

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Initially present during the acute phase of infection, indicating active infection. It will eventually drop and become negative upon recovery.

 

Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): Initially, anti-HBc IgM is positive during the acute phase, which then transitions to anti-HBc IgG as the infection progresses. The total anti-HBc represents both IgM initially and IgG later on.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity. It decreases as the virus is cleared.

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): The protective antibody indicating recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This antibody appears after the disappearance of HBsAg and is a marker of immunity post-recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti HBc: Anti-HBc indicates past or current infection with hepatitis B. Initially, IgM anti-HBc is present during the acute infection, and later, IgG anti-HBc persists. However, it does not specifically indicate recovery and immunity.


Option C. HBeAg: HBeAg is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is present during the active infection phase and decreases as the infection resolves.


Option D. HBsAg: HBsAg indicates active hepatitis B infection. It is present during the acute phase of infection and disappears upon recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBs antibodies indicate recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This is the only protective antibody that signifies the patient has successfully recovered from the infection and has developed immunity.

choices.text: Endobronchial neoplasm
Bronchial asthma
Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myasthenia gravis

 

In patient 1, flow volume curve shows restrictive pattern, and it corresponds to myasthenia gravis.

 

The flow volume curve shown indicates a restrictive pattern, which is characterized by reduced lung volumes but relatively preserved flow rates, consistent with non-obstructive lung pathology. Myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder, often affects the respiratory muscles leading to a restrictive ventilatory defect as depicted in the flow volume loop. This condition results from antibodies that block or destroy nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the junction between the nerve and muscle, leading to muscle weakness including the respiratory muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endobronchial neoplasm: Typically presents with an obstructive pattern on spirometry due to airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: Asthma would show an obstructive pattern characterized by decreased peak expiratory flow and difficulty exhaling, which is not observed in the given curve.

 

Option D. Emphysema: Emphysema, part of chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD), would also exhibit an obstructive pattern with a "scooped out" appearance on the expiratory curve due to air trapping and reduced elastic recoil, which is not seen in the curve provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis can present with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests due to respiratory muscle weakness, differentiating it from conditions that cause obstructive patterns such as asthma and emphysema.

questions.text: 52-year-old man collapses and you are giving CPR with your friend. What is the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30:2

 

In adult life support, the standard ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers. This ratio ensures that there is an adequate number of compressions to maintain circulation, while also providing necessary breaths to maintain oxygenation

 

In pediatric Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS), the ratio can vary depending on the number of rescuers. If there is only one rescuer, the ratio remains 30:2. However, if there are two rescuers, the ratio can change to 15:2.

For neonates, the ratio is different, typically 3:1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adult CPR, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is always 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers.

choices.text: CT guided biopsy
Sputum for AFB

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. CXR shows a 3 cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT guided biopsy

 

The patient has several risk factors for lung cancer, including being over 40 years old, a significant smoking history, and the presence of a mass larger than 2 cm on the chest X-ray. Given these factors, the likelihood of the mass being malignant is high. A CT guided biopsy is the best next step because it allows for precise sampling of the mass to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchoscopy: This would be appropriate if the mass were centrally located or if there were signs of endobronchial involvement. However, because the mass is in the upper lobe, CT guided biopsy is preferred.

 

Option C. Sputum cytology: This test can sometimes detect cancer cells in the sputum, but it is less reliable, especially for peripheral lung lesions.

 

Option D. Sputum for AFB: This test is used to detect tuberculosis. Given the patient's history and presentation, tuberculosis is less likely than lung cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a significant smoking history and a peripheral lung mass larger than 2 cm, a CT guided biopsy is the next best step to diagnose the nature of the mass.

choices.text: Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

WISKOTT-ALDRICH SYNDROME (WAS)

 

  • It is a complex, recessive, X-linked disease

 

Mutations:

 

  • WASP gene (affect not only T lymphocytes but also the other lymphocyte subsets, dendritic cells, and platelets).

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • WASP regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting cell and target cells.

 

Clinical manifestations:

 

  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Eczema
  • Bleeding caused by thrombocytopenia
  • Null mutations predispose affected individuals to invasive and bronchopulmonary infections, viral infections, severe eczema, and autoimmune manifestations.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Reduced-sized platelets on a blood smear.
  • Intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASP) expression in blood cells.

 

Treatment:

 

  • According to the severity of disease expression.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and careful topical treatment of eczema.
  • Although splenectomy improves platelet count in a majority of cases, this intervention is associated with a significant risk of infection (both before and after HSCT).
  • Allogeneic HSCT is curative, with fairly good results overall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B:  Chediak higashi occurs due to LyST (Lysosomal transfer protein) defect characterized by recurrent infections, oculo-cutaneous albinism

 

Option C: TAR is associated with thrombocytopenia at birth

 

Option D:  Hermansky-Pudlak occurs due to deficiency of dense granules in platelets characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, ILD, Granulomatous colitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is distinguished by its symptom triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections, directly related to mutations in the WASP gene affecting cellular function and immune response. Understanding these features is critical in diagnosing the syndrome and managing its complex clinical manifestations effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Immunodeficiencies/Chapter 351,374

choices.text: Acute kidney injury (AKI)
Chronic renal failure

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

 

The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease) criteria are specifically designed to classify and diagnose Acute Kidney Injury (AKI). These criteria help in early detection and grading the severity of AKI based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and duration of symptoms.

 

Current diagnosis is based on the KDIGO group criteria. Urine output (OR) Creatinine rise is considered in the diagnosis.

 

KDIGO group criteria for diagnosis of AKI:

 

  1. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 0.3mg/dL.
  2. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 1.5 times of baseline that is known/presumed to have occur in the past 7 days.
  3. Urine volume < 0.5ml/kg/hour for 6 hours.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute glomerulonephritis: This has specific clinical and laboratory features distinct from AKI.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: Characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over months to years.

 

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome: Defined by high levels of protein in the urine, low levels of protein in the blood, high levels of cholesterol, and swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AKIN and RIFLE criteria are essential tools for diagnosing and assessing the severity of Acute Kidney Injury, which can guide interventions and predict outcomes in affected patients. They emphasize changes in serum creatinine and urine output as key indicators of kidney function.

questions.text: Dialysis disequilibrium occurs due to:(NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reverse urea effect

 

Explanation:

 

Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) is characterized by neurologic symptoms of varying severity, primarily due to cerebral edema. This condition is most commonly attributed to the "reverse urea effect." During hemodialysis, urea is removed from the blood more quickly than from the brain, creating an osmotic gradient. This causes water to flow into the brain, leading to cerebral edema and increased intracranial pressure. Symptoms of DDS include headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, muscle twitching, disorientation, delirium, hypertension, tremors, and seizures. The condition is typically self-limiting and improves with time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Although hypertension can be a complication of dialysis, it is not the primary cause of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.

 

Option C. Aluminum toxicity: Aluminum toxicity can cause encephalopathy in dialysis patients, but it is not related to the acute neurologic symptoms seen in dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.

 

Option D. Amyloid deposition: Amyloid deposition occurs in long-term dialysis patients and can lead to dialysis-related amyloidosis, but it is not responsible for the acute symptoms of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome occurs primarily due to the "reverse urea effect," where a rapid reduction of urea in the blood during dialysis creates an osmotic gradient, leading to water influx into the brain and subsequent cerebral edema.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. She also has dysphagia. On examination, dental caries and enlarged cervical lymph nodes are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sjogren syndrome

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are characteristic of Sjogren syndrome:

 

  • Dryness in the mouth and eyes (xerostomia and keratoconjunctivitis sicca): These are hallmark features of Sjogren syndrome, caused by lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of the salivary and lacrimal glands.
  • Dysphagia: This can occur due to reduced saliva production, making swallowing difficult.
  • Dental caries: Poor saliva production leads to an increased risk of dental caries because saliva helps protect against tooth decay.
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes: Lymphadenopathy can be associated with Sjogren syndrome due to chronic inflammation.

 

Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disease primarily affecting the exocrine glands, leading to dry mouth and eyes, among other systemic manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed connective tissue disorders: These involve features of several autoimmune diseases (such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis) but do not typically present with the classic symptoms of dry mouth and eyes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This can cause dry eyes and mouth but is more commonly associated with lung involvement and other systemic symptoms.

 

Option C. Wegener's granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis): This condition involves vasculitis and can affect the respiratory tract and kidneys, but it does not typically present with the primary symptoms of dry mouth and eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, dysphagia, dental caries, and lymphadenopathy, due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands.

choices.text: Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A patient with renal failure develops vomiting in ICU. ABG analysis showed pH - 7.4, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L, HC03- = 24mEq/L, PaC02 = 40 mmHg. What is the likely metabolic abnormality? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

 

Clinical history of renal failure should hint towards possibility of preexisting metabolic acidosis. Important in MCQs to always calculate AG even if ABG appears normal.

 

AG: 145-(100+24) = 21 (Normal ~12)

 

Excess unmeasured anion(H) combines with HCO3 thereby reducing the HCO3 proportionately.

 

Hence Delta ratio i.e., ΔAG(AG-12) /ΔHCO3(24-HCO3) = >2.

 

Value >2 indicate coexisting Metabolic alkalosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ABG: The pH is indeed normal, but the underlying disturbances (as reflected by an increased anion gap) indicate that the system is not normal.

 

Option B. Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis: The anion gap is increased, ruling out normal anion gap acidosis.

 

Option D. High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis: This choice incorrectly identifies the nature of acid-base disturbances, confusing the interpretation and relationship between anion gap and bicarbonate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with renal failure and symptoms like vomiting, it's crucial to evaluate both the anion gap and changes in bicarbonate to identify complex acid-base disturbances such as the coexistence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

choices.text: Start IV fluids with large bore cannula
Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
Take the patient to the ICU and intubate

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

 

History is suggestive of tension pneumothorax and hence immediate decompression is required to maintain hemodynamic stability. Definitive management involves insertion of Chest tube/Pigtail in the triangle of safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start IV fluids with large bore cannula: While IV fluids are important in managing hypotension, they do not address the immediate life-threatening issue of tension pneumothorax and might actually exacerbate the patient's condition by increasing venous return and further compressing the heart.

 

Option C. Take the patient to the ICU and intubate: Intubation in the setting of tension pneumothorax without prior decompression can worsen the patients hemodynamic status by increasing intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Start positive pressure ventilation: Positive pressure ventilation could potentially increase the pressure in the pleural cavity, worsening the tension pneumothorax and leading to rapid hemodynamic deterioration.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is critical to stabilize the patient and prevent further cardiovascular compromise. This emergency procedure is a life-saving intervention that precedes further definitive management like chest tube insertion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Pneumothorax/ Chap 294

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presented with arthritis. She had a history of fever and sore throat 1 week ago. On examination, you hear a pansystolic murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. What is the finding you will see in the biopsy? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aschoff nodule

 

The clinical presentation suggests acute rheumatic fever (ARF), a sequela of untreated or poorly treated streptococcal pharyngitis. ARF can manifest with migratory arthritis, carditis (evidenced by the pansystolic murmur indicative of mitral regurgitation), and other systemic symptoms.

 

Aschoff nodules, or Aschoff bodies, are pathognomonic for acute rheumatic fever. These are areas of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by chronic inflammatory cells, including Anitschkow cells (macrophages with characteristic wavy nuclei). They are found in the heart tissue, especially in the myocardium, and are a hallmark of rheumatic carditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomyxoma: Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a condition characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity, typically originating from a mucinous tumor. It is not related to acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Caseating granuloma: Caseating granulomas are characteristic of tuberculosis and certain fungal infections. They consist of a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of activated macrophages and lymphocytes. This finding is not associated with rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Verrucous tumour: Verrucous tumors are typically warty growths and are not related to rheumatic fever. They can be associated with certain types of skin cancers or infectious warts but have no connection to the condition described in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of sore throat followed by symptoms such as arthritis and carditis, acute rheumatic fever should be considered. The presence of Aschoff nodules in biopsy is pathognomonic for this condition, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male recently underwent Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG). Within a few days after taking a saphenous vein graft, he complained of pain in the legs, and on examination, he had mild sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot on the side from where the graft was harvested. What is the nerve likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Saphenous nerve

 

The saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve that provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the leg and foot. During coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), the saphenous vein is often harvested for use as a graft. Due to its close anatomical relationship with the saphenous nerve, the nerve can be inadvertently injured during the vein harvesting process.

 

Injury to the saphenous nerve typically results in sensory disturbances such as pain, numbness, or tingling in the medial aspect of the leg and foot, which matches the patient's presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial peroneal nerve: The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot. Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss in these areas, not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve supplies the lateral aspect of the foot and the posterior lower leg. Injury to the sural nerve would not affect the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the posterior compartment of the leg and the sole of the foot. Injury to the tibial nerve would affect these areas rather than the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The saphenous nerve, due to its proximity to the saphenous vein, is at risk of injury during saphenous vein harvesting for CABG, leading to sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

choices.text: Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology
IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control
DC Cardioversion is required in all cases
Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man collapsed and was brought to the emergency. ECG was taken and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) was made. Which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control

 

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves on ECG, which confirms the diagnosis. Each of the provided options needs to be evaluated for accuracy.

 

IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control. This is the correct statement. IV Digoxin is used for rate control in AF, particularly in patients with heart failure.

 

If the patient is stable and not in acute heart failure, beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem are preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology: This statement is incorrect. Atrial fibrillation can occur in morphologically normal hearts. Studies indicate that 15-35% of AF cases can be seen in individuals with structurally normal hearts, although it is more common in those with conditions such as heart failure or left atrial enlargement.

 

Option C. DC Cardioversion is required in all cases: This statement is incorrect. DC cardioversion is reserved for unstable patients or for rhythm control in selected chronic cases. It is not required for all AF cases.

 

Option D. Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis: This statement is incorrect. While a pulse deficit (difference between heart rate and pulse rate) can suggest AF, it is not a reliable diagnostic criterion as it can be observed in other conditions such as frequent ventricular premature contractions, cardiac tamponade, and severe heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV Digoxin can be effectively used for ventricular rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in those with heart failure.

choices.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.text: A diabetic nephropathy patient is an ideal candidate for renal graft transplant. Which of the following statements is true? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

 

In the absence of graft rejection, transplantation is financially advantageous for a patient with diabetic nephropathy. When compared to two years of dialysis, transplant surgery is less expensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graft survival rate is ~80-82% at the end of first year.

 

Option B. The life expectancy of a patient with diabetic nephropathy is not doubled post-transplant.

 

Option D. Chronic graft rejection following renal transplantation is referred to as chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN) which consists of tubular atrophy, glomerulosclerosis, fibrosis of the renal interstitium, and fibrous thickening of the arteries.

 

HLA mismatching, acute episodes of graft rejection, age mismatch between donor and recipient, smoking, and acute episodes of graft rejection are risk factors that put a recipient at risk for long-term graft rejection. Treatment is difficult and no significant improvement has been seen over last 10 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal transplantation becomes cost-effective after the second year post-transplant for diabetic nephropathy patients compared to ongoing dialysis. This consideration, coupled with improved quality of life and potential prolongation of life expectancy, makes it a favorable option for suitable candidates.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Yogurt

 

Yogurt is the least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance among the options listed. This is because yogurt contains live bacteria, specifically lactobacilli, which help to break down lactose. This fermentation process reduces the lactose content significantly, making yogurt easier to digest for individuals with lactase deficiency. Additionally, these bacteria can contribute to the production of some lactase enzyme, aiding in the digestion of any remaining lactose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skimmed Milk: Contains nearly the same amount of lactose as regular milk, just with less fat. It is likely to cause symptoms in someone with lactose intolerance.

 

Option B. Condensed Milk: Even higher in lactose because it is milk that has been concentrated by removing water. High lactose content makes it more likely to cause intolerance symptoms.

 

Option C. Ice-cream: Typically high in lactose because it is made from cream and milk, both of which are high in lactose. Ice cream can also contain mix-ins and flavorings that increase the lactose content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yogurt contains lactobacillus, that helps in lactase production and also low lactose levels.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastroenterology/Diarrhea/chap 471

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. His HRCT thorax is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

 

In patients with HIV and respiratory failure, findings of GGO & cysts within GGO in perihilar locations on HRCT are characteristic for PCP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcal pneumonia: This typically presents with more localized consolidations or cavitary lesions rather than the diffuse, bilateral ground-glass opacities seen in PCP.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal pneumonia: Often manifests as lobar consolidation, which does not match the diffuse pattern observed in the HRCT.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: In HIV-positive patients, tuberculosis may present in various forms including miliary patterns or cavitary disease, especially if the CD4 count is low, but the diffuse ground-glass appearance is more characteristic of PCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Opportunistic Infection in HIV/Chap

questions.text: Bilateral upper limb pulseless disease is?( NEET PG  2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Takayasu arteritis

 

Explanation:

 

Takayasu arteritis, also known as Aorto-Arteritis, is a form of large vessel granulomatous vasculitis characterized by massive intimal fibrosis and vascular narrowing. It is known as the "pulseless disease" due to the obstruction of the main branches of the aorta, including the brachiocephalic artery on the right and the subclavian and common carotid arteries on the left. This results in feeble or absent pulses in both upper extremities (bilateral upper limb pulseless disease).

 

Takayasu Disease:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Involves all three layers of the arterial wall causing extensive intimal proliferation, inflammation of media and adventitia followed by marked fibrous scarring.
  • Histology: Shows round cell infiltration, cuffing of vasa vasorum, and destruction of tunica media leading to gross fibrosis.
  • Also Known As: Aortic arch syndrome, non-specific aortoarteritis, pulseless disease, and reversed coarctation.
  • Clinical Presentation: Feeble or absent pulses in both upper extremities, hypertension (due to renal artery stenosis).

 

Comparison:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giant Cell Arteritis: Typically affects the temporal arteries and does not cause bilateral upper limb pulseless disease.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis Nodosa: Affects medium-sized arteries and does not commonly present with bilateral upper limb pulseless disease.

 

Option D. Coarctation of Aorta: Causes diminished pulses in the lower extremities, not the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis is characterized by diminished or absent pulses in both upper extremities, earning it the name "pulseless disease"

choices.text: Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease
Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition
Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease

 

Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. It is characterized by a patchy distribution of inflammation, which is often transmural (affecting the entire thickness of the bowel wall). Skeletions, also known as skip lesions, are a hallmark feature of Crohn's disease, where areas of inflamed tissue are interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease typically involves transmural inflammation, meaning it affects all layers of the bowel wall. On the other hand, ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that is limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition: While there are genetic factors associated with IBD, such as mutations in the NOD2/CARD15 gene linked to Crohn's disease, the overall genetic predisposition is not considered strong. Environmental factors play a more significant role in the development of IBD.

 

Option D. Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and is not curable by surgical resection. Surgery can help manage symptoms and complications but does not cure the disease. Ulcerative colitis, however, can be cured by surgical removal of the colon and rectum (total proctocolectomy).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skepletions (skip lesions) are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of multiple copper sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas reveals metabolic acidosis and serum copper levels are elevated. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dimercaprol

 

Explanation:


Copper sulfate poisoning can cause gastrointestinal irritation, hemolysis, hepatotoxicity, and metabolic acidosis. Elevated serum copper levels confirm systemic toxicity. The management includes:

  • Dimercaprol: A chelating agent that binds copper, reducing its toxicity and promoting excretion. It is the primary treatment for acute copper poisoning.
  • Supportive care to manage complications such as acidosis and dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whole Bowel Irrigation: Incorrect because WBI is more effective in managing ingestion of substances that are visible on abdominal X-ray (e.g., iron tablets) but is not the primary treatment for systemic copper toxicity.

 

Option B. Activated Charcoal: Incorrect because activated charcoal does not adsorb metals like copper, iron, or lead, making it ineffective in copper sulfate poisoning.

 

Option D. Deferoxamine: Incorrect because deferoxamine is specific for iron poisoning and has no chelating action against copper.

 

Educational Objective:


Dimercaprol is the chelating agent of choice for acute copper poisoning. Prompt recognition and treatment are critical to prevent severe complications such as hemolysis and multiorgan failure. Whole bowel irrigation and activated charcoal are not effective for heavy metal poisoning.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the most useful diagnostic investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT Thorax

 

CECT is preferred when suspicion of malignancy is high. HRCT is preferred to look at lung parenchyma/suspected ILD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI is used to assess for metastasis, secondary changes. MRI is NOT preferred over CT scan for evaluation of distant metastasis and invasion.

 

Option B. Bronchoscopy is used for biopsy of mass based on accessibility. More central masses are amenable to bronchoscopic biopsy. Peripheral masses are sampled by CT-guided biopsy.

 

Option D. Bronchography is no longer used in todays practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The choice of CT Thorax (HRCT or CECT) is critical for early detection of potential malignancies or other significant lung conditions in a high-risk individual, particularly when initial less sensitive tests like chest X-ray and sputum analysis have failed to elucidate the cause of symptoms.

 

Reference - (Harrison 21E, 597,598) Resp Med/Hemoptysis/Lung CA

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular therapy develops tingling sensation in the limbs. Which of the following when substituted can result from in improvement of symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

 

This is a case of peripheral neuropathy that occurs in ATT therapy due to isoniazid (INH)

 

To treat this – Pyridoxine 10-25mg/day should be added to regimen.

 

High risk patients for peripheral neuropathy include- malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetes, HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: While important for nervous system function, thiamine is not typically depleted by INH therapy.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Not directly related to the neurological side effects of INH.

 

Option D. Methylcobalamin: Though important for nerve health, it is not the primary vitamin depleted by INH therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is essential for patients receiving isoniazid as part of their anti-tubercular therapy to prevent or manage peripheral neuropathy symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by the presence of specific tumors and physical features. This syndrome is often referred to as "Triple M syndrome" because it commonly presents with three key features: mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid body habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. In addition, pheochromocytomas may also occur.

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) that produce calcitonin. MTC is a hallmark of MEN 2B, making it one of the primary diagnostic criteria for the syndrome.

 

The condition is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, specifically the codon 918 mutation on chromosome 10, which leads to the development of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Café au lait spot: Café au lait spots are not characteristic of MEN 2B syndrome. These pigmented skin lesions are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and, in some cases, tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Parathyroid adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are typically seen in patients with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, not in MEN 2B. These adenomas cause hyperparathyroidism, which is not a feature of MEN 2B.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve gliomas are primarily associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are not a feature of MEN 2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Only aspirin is given
  2. Warfarin is given
  3. Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated
  4. Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

For a patient with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, particularly one with a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA), anticoagulation therapy is essential.

 

2. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant in cases of severe mitral stenosis due to its proven effectiveness in preventing thromboembolic events.

 

3. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in this scenario as they are not indicated for patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Aspirin alone is insufficient to prevent stroke in this context.

 

4. Mitral valvotomy is not recommended at this point because performing the procedure could dislodge existing clots, leading to embolic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, especially those with a history of TIA, Warfarin should be given for stroke prevention, and direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126 mEq/L, AST: 62, ALT: 56, RBS: 112 mg/dL, and serum bilirubin of 0.8 mg%. Which of the following organisms is responsible? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legionella

 

The patient's presentation includes a constellation of symptoms and laboratory findings indicative of Legionella pneumonia, also known as Legionnaires' disease. Key features supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • High-grade fever, cough, and confusion: Common symptoms of Legionella pneumonia.
  • Diarrhea: Gastrointestinal manifestations are frequently associated with Legionella infections.
  • Bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray: Legionella pneumonia typically presents with infiltrates rather than consolidation.
  • Hyponatremia (Na: 126 mEq/L): Commonly seen in Legionella due to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).
  • Elevated liver enzymes (AST: 62, ALT: 56): Transaminitis is often observed in Legionella infections.
  • Normal bilirubin and random blood sugar levels: These findings are not specific but do not rule out Legionella.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus: Streptococcal pneumonia usually presents with lobar consolidation and does not commonly cause significant gastrointestinal symptoms or hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis jiroveci: This organism typically affects immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS) and presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates rather than focal infiltrates and lacks gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Option D. Klebsiella: Klebsiella pneumonia usually presents with lobar consolidation and "currant jelly" sputum. It does not typically cause gastrointestinal symptoms or hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, diarrhea, bilateral lung infiltrates, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes, Legionella pneumonia should be strongly suspected.

choices.text: 1 & 3; a, c, d
2 & 4; b, c, e
1 & 3; a, d
2 & 4; b, e

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

Clinical findings

 

a. Pulsus bisferiens

b. Pulsus alternans

c. Ejection systolic murmur

d. Murmur increases on standing

e. Murmur decreases on standing

 

Management

 

1. Beta-blockers are given

2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated

3. ICD is indicated

4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

The echocardiography findings and symptoms are indicative of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, due to the thickening of the heart muscle, there is a dynamic obstruction to blood flow, often worsening with decreased preload, such as when standing.

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a) is commonly observed in conditions like HCM, where there are two distinct peaks in arterial pulse per cardiac cycle due to the dynamic obstruction.
  • Ejection systolic murmur (c) is typical in HCM and is due to the obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • Murmur increases on standing (d) in HCM due to increased obstruction with reduced venous return.

 

Regarding management:

 

  • Beta-blockers (1) are typically used in HCM to manage symptoms and reduce heart rate, thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand and the degree of obstruction.
  • ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) (3) is recommended in patients with HCM who are at high risk of sudden cardiac death.

ICD indicated for all patients with ≥1 risk factor for SCD or HCM-AF score >6%

 

MAVACAMTEN is recently approved drug which modulates b-myosin heavy chain (↓Bridging & Inotropy) & reduces the need for ablation by 80% in long term

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This is incorrect as it suggests that beta-blockers are contraindicated and includes "murmur decreases on standing," which is not characteristic of HCM. Pulsus alternans (b), indicative of severe heart failure, is not typical in HCM without heart failure.

 

Option C. It misses the key management and diagnostic features by excluding the ejection systolic murmur, which is a significant finding in HCM.

 

Option D. This incorrectly includes beta-blockers as contraindicated and excludes the key symptom of an ejection systolic murmur. It also incorrectly suggests that ICD is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Points:

 

  • All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: Which among the following according to the latest guidelines is NOT an indication to IE prophylaxis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atrial Septal Defect

 

According to the latest guidelines, there are specific indications for infective endocarditis (IE) prophylaxis to prevent infection in high-risk patients. These indications include:

 

  1. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Patients with a history of infective endocarditis are at increased risk for recurrence and hence, are recommended for prophylaxis.
  2. Prosthetic Valves: Patients with prosthetic heart valves, especially mechanical valves, are susceptible to infections and require prophylaxis.
  3. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Those who have undergone cardiac transplant and have developed valvulopathy are also indicated for IE prophylaxis.
  4. Congenital Heart Disease: This includes any unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, repaired congenital heart disease with prosthetic material for the first six months post-repair, or repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects.

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not listed among these high-risk conditions. ASD, especially without significant gradient across the atria or significant shunting, has a very low risk of causing infective endocarditis. Therefore, ASD does not fit into the current guidelines for IE prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Prior infective endocarditis significantly increases the risk of recurrent infection, thus requiring IE prophylaxis as per the guidelines.

 

Option C. Unrepaired Cyanotic Congenital Heart Disease: Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease is a high-risk condition for infective endocarditis, necessitating prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Patients who have undergone a cardiac transplant and have valvulopathy are at increased risk for infection and are indicated for IE prophylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not an indication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis according to the latest guidelines, whereas prior infective endocarditis, prosthetic valves, cardiac transplant with valvulopathy, and certain congenital heart diseases are key indications.

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Reduced serum iron level

2.Reduced transferrin saturation

3.Increased total iron binding capacity

4.Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4


Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is characterized by reduced ferritin, which is the one of the first indicators of IDA, ferritin indicates the iron stores in the body. Serum iron levels will drop after ferritin levels decrease. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) will increase. Transferrin saturation, a measure of iron and TIBC, will reduce. Transferrin saturation is less than 18%, but less than 20% indicates iron deficiency anemia.

 

  1. Reduced serum iron level: Low iron levels in the blood.
  2. Reduced transferrin saturation: Less iron available for transport.
  3. Increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC): The body produces more transferrin to capture iron.
  4. Reduced ferritin level: Indicates low iron stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia involves reduced serum iron, reduced transferrin saturation, increased TIBC, and reduced ferritin levels

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via an increase in cAMP. The steps involved in this mechanism are given below. Which of the following is the correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Activation of PKA
  3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that act via an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) follow a specific sequence of events in the signal transduction pathway. The steps involved are as follows:

 

1. Activation of Adenylate Cyclase: Upon ligand binding to the G-stimulatory GPCR, the receptor activates adenylate cyclase.

 

3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP: The activated adenylate cyclase converts ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP).

 

2. Activation of Protein Kinase A (PKA): The increased levels of cAMP activate protein kinase A (PKA).

 

4. Phosphorylation of Target Proteins: PKA then phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to the desired cellular response.

 

This sequence of events accurately describes the cAMP signal transduction pathway activated by G-stimulatory GPCRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway activated by G-stimulatory GPCRs is: Activation of adenylate cyclase, conversion of ATP to cAMP, activation of PKA, and phosphorylation of target proteins.

questions.text: 65-year-old lady with a history of COPD and cor pulmonale presents with breathlessness and frequent exacerbations. Which of the following will improve survival in this patient?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long-term O2 therapy

 

For patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), there are only a few interventions proven to improve survival. These include smoking cessation, long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) for those who qualify, and lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) in selected patients. LTOT is particularly beneficial for patients with severe hypoxemia, as it helps maintain adequate oxygen levels, reducing the risk of heart failure and other complications associated with chronic hypoxemia.

 

In this case, the presence of cor pulmonale, which is a condition secondary to long-standing COPD leading to right heart failure, further strengthens the indication for LTOT. This therapy can help manage symptoms and prevent further deterioration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulization with budesonide: While this may help in managing symptoms of COPD by reducing inflammation and preventing exacerbations, it does not have a proven impact on improving overall survival.

 

Option C. Pneumococcal vaccine: This can reduce the risk of pneumococcal infections, which are common in COPD patients, but it does not directly improve survival in the long-term management of COPD.

 

Option D. Positive Pressure Ventilation:  This can be useful in managing acute exacerbations of COPD or chronic respiratory failure, but it is not typically used as a long-term therapy to improve survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) is one of the few interventions that improve survival in patients with COPD, especially those with severe hypoxemia and complications like cor pulmonale.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid hemorrhage

 

A subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a life-threatening condition characterized by bleeding into the space surrounding the brain, leading to sudden, severe headaches often described as the "worst headache of my life." This patient’s symptoms, including a severe headache of sudden onset, hypertension, and nuchal rigidity (neck stiffness), are classic signs of SAH.

 

The CT scan provided shows diffuse blood in the subarachnoid space, which is a hallmark of this condition. The presence of blood in the sulci, gyri, and ventricles, and the star-shaped appearance of the blood distribution on the CT scan (referred to as the "star of death" sign) further confirms this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cluster headache: Incorrect. While cluster headaches can be severe, they are typically unilateral and associated with autonomic symptoms such as tearing and nasal congestion, not nuchal rigidity or hypertension.

 

Option C. Encephalitis: Incorrect. Encephalitis can present with headache, fever, and altered mental status, but it does not typically cause nuchal rigidity or hypertension, and the CT findings would differ.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Incorrect. Meningitis can present with headache, fever, and nuchal rigidity, but it is usually accompanied by fever and altered mental status. The CT scan findings would show inflammation of the meninges rather than bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with sudden, severe headache, nuchal rigidity, and hypertension. CT scan shows blood in the subarachnoid space, appearing as a "star of death."

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with fatigue, malaise, and no jaundice. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (Twisted PYQ)

  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Negative
  • Anti-HBc (IgG): Positive
  • HBsAg: Positive
  • Anti-HBs: Negative
  • Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chronic hepatitis B

 

Explanation:


Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed based on the persistence of HBsAg for more than six months along with the presence of IgG anti-HBc (indicating past exposure). The absence of IgM anti-HBc confirms that this is not an acute infection. Additional serologic markers support this diagnosis:

  • HBsAg positive: Indicates ongoing infection.
  • IgG anti-HBc positive: Reflects prior exposure to the hepatitis B virus.
  • Anti-HBs negative: Suggests that immunity has not been achieved (either naturally or through vaccination).

Chronic hepatitis B may present without overt symptoms such as jaundice and can remain asymptomatic or progress to complications such as cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute hepatitis B: Incorrect because IgM anti-HBc is negative, ruling out acute infection. Acute hepatitis B is characterized by positive HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc.

 

Option C. Resolved hepatitis B infection: Incorrect because in resolved infection, HBsAg is negative and anti-HBs is positive, indicating immunity.

 

Option D. Acute hepatitis C: Incorrect because anti-HCV antibodies are negative, ruling out hepatitis C as the cause of the symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:


Chronic hepatitis B is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg and the presence of IgG anti-HBc. Differentiating acute from chronic hepatitis B is critical for appropriate management and long-term monitoring to prevent complications like cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient has right upper limb BP of >180/95 mmHg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mmHg. He also has early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supravalvular aortic stenosis.

 

An early diastolic murmur in the right 2nd intercostal space is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely to be associated with the above findings.

 

BP difference between arms is classical due to blood jet projected towards right brachiocephalic artery, but the murmur of AR is very rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coarctation of the Aorta: Can sometimes show differences in arm blood pressures, especially if the coarctation is proximal to the left subclavian artery. It is also associated with a bicuspid aortic valve, which can lead to AR.

 

Option C. Takayasu Arteritis: Known for causing vascular inflammation leading to stenoses, which can result in differing blood pressures in the arms. About 25% of patients may also have AR.

 

Option D. Aortic Dissection: Typically presents with differential blood pressure between arms and can rapidly lead to AR due to involvement of the aortic root.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While differential arm blood pressure can suggest several cardiovascular anomalies, supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely among the options given to be associated with these findings, especially concerning the presence of a diastolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation.

choices.text: Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg

questions.text: All are components of CURB65 except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Systolic blood pressure less than 10mm Hg

 

The correct answer, D, specifies a systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg, which is not part of the CURB-65 criteria. The specified threshold for blood pressure in the CURB-65 is 90 mm Hg systolic or 60 mm Hg diastolic.

 

CURB-65 criteria is used to assess the severity of illness in case of pneumonia, especially community acquired pneumonia. It includes 5 variables -

 

C - Confusion

 

U - Urea>7mmol/L
